forecast.review: Both forecasters largely reinforce the same core points I used: (1) the latest print at 247k and a 4‑week average around 235k put the baseline above 220k; (2) corroborating indicators (Challenger cuts, Beige Book/ISM tone) point to softening; (3) weekly claims are noisy so we shouldn’t be at near‑certainty. Forecaster 3’s quantification that a No outcome implies ~an 11% drop from 247k within three weeks is a useful framing, though it doesn’t materially change my prior. I do think both analyses slightly underweight two countervailing risks: (a) holiday/seasonal quirks around the target week (Juneteenth falls within the June 21 reference week and can affect filing/reporting patterns; seasonal factors are still adapting to this relatively new federal holiday), and (b) state‑specific reversals after temporary spikes (e.g., autos, localized layoffs) that can produce a sharp weekly downtick. On the flip side, they correctly emphasize that the moving average inertia and breadth of softening indicators make a quick return to ≤220k less likely.
forecast.rationale: Baseline: With the 4‑week SA average ~235k and the latest weekly at 247k, the central tendency for late June is still above 220k. Even with mean reversion toward ~230k, the threshold would likely be exceeded. Historical week‑to‑week volatility in SA claims (~8–12k) implies that dropping from 247k to ≤220k within three weeks is possible but a low‑tail outcome. Evidence cross‑checks (rising announced cuts, softer surveys) reduce the odds of a swift, fundamental improvement by the target week. Counter‑risks: The week ended June 21 includes Juneteenth, which can depress filings in that week and shift them into adjacent weeks; seasonal adjustment may not fully neutralize this, slightly increasing the chance of a dip. Also, some late‑May state spikes (e.g., autos) could reverse. Netting these, I still see the modal outcome as >220k, but I keep probability shy of mid‑80s to reflect holiday/weekly-noise risk and potential mean reversion. I’m nudging my forecast up a hair in light of the other forecasters’ emphasis on the magnitude of decline required and the consistent multi‑indicator softening, but I’m not moving much because those points were already in my base case.
